conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks the path of light.
The shape and size of the shadow depend on the position and distance of the light source relative to the object and the surface where the shadow is cast.
When the light source is closer to the object, the shadow is larger and more distorted.
When the light source is farther away, the shadow is smaller and more similar in shape to the object.
The light source is positioned such that it casts shadows A, B, C, and D as shown in the image.
These shadows are relatively large and somewhat distorted, indicating that the light source is not very far from the objects.
When the light source moves forward (closer to the objects), the shadows will move backward (away from the objects).
The shadows will become smaller because the light source is now closer to the objects.
Shadow A, cast by the mushrooms, will move backward and become smaller.
Shadow B, cast by the small object near the top right, will move backward and become smaller.
Shadow C, cast by the white object with handles, will move backward and become smaller.
Shadow D, cast by the book, will move backward and become smaller.
When the light source moves forward above the objects, shadows A, B, C, and D will all move backward and become smaller in size.
